member.name: T:ModelText.ModelEditControl.XmlHeaderType
member.summary: Defines what type of header should be inserted at the top, when you invoke the method of the interface.

member.name: F:ModelText.ModelEditControl.XmlHeaderType.Xml
member.summary:
Specifies that there should be an XML header (but not an XHTML header), which looks like this:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>

member.name: F:ModelText.ModelEditControl.XmlHeaderType.Xhtml
member.summary:
Specifies that there should be a full XHTML header, which looks like this:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <!DOCTYPE html PUBLIC "-//W3C//DTD XHTML 1.1//EN" "http://www.w3.org/TR/xhtml11/DTD/xhtml11.dtd">

member.name: F:ModelText.ModelEditControl.XmlHeaderType.None
member.summary: Specifies that there should be no header at all.

member.summary: Initializes the contents of the control, using an entire XHTML document.
member.param:
A instance from which the control can read an XHTML document. TextReader is an abstract class, so this parameter will actually be a subclass of TextReader: for example it may be a
in order to read the document from a file on disk; or, it may be a
if the document is stored in a string.

member.name: M:ModelText.ModelEditControl.IModelEdit.openDocumentFragment(System.String,System.IO.TextReader)
member.summary: Initializes the contents of the control, using a partial fragment (a subtree) of an XHTML document.
member.param:
A string which identifies the root element of the specified document fragment. For example, if the document fragment is "

Hello

" then the value of this parameter should be "body". This root element must also be a block element like "div" or "body", and not just an inline element like "span" or "strong".

A instance from which the control can read the document fragment. TextReader is an abstract class, so this parameter will actually be a subclass of TextReader: for example it may be a
in order to read the document from a file on disk; or, it may be a
if the document is stored in a string.

member.name: M:ModelText.ModelEditControl.IModelEdit.openDefaultTestDocument(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Initializes the contents of the control, using a built-in default document which is used for testing.
member.remarks: The content of the built-in default document may vary from one version to another of the HTML control.
member.param: This boolean parameter specifies whether or not the test document should be a form (i.e. should contain an HTML form element and form controls).

member.name: M:ModelText.ModelEditControl.IModelEdit.save(System.IO.TextWriter,ModelText.ModelEditControl.XmlHeaderType)
member.summary: Gets a string whose value is the serialized HTML contents of the document (or document fragment) in the control.
member.param:
A instance into which the control can write the document (or document fragment). TextWriter is an abstract class, so this parameter will actually be a subclass of TextWriter: for example it may be a
in order to write the document from a file on disk; or, it may be a
if the document should be serialized to a string.

A instance, which specifies what type of header should be written:
You should probably specify XmlHeaderType.Xhtml if you're writing a whole document, especially if you're writing it to a disk file.
Alternatively, if the control contains a document fragment instead of a whole document (because you initialized it using the method instead of the method, then you should probably specify XmlHeaderType.Xml if you're writing the document fragment to disk.
Otherwise, you may prefer to specify XmlHeaderType.None if you're writing the document fragment to a string, especially if you're intending to concatenate it with other documents fragments (you wouldn't want headers embedded between concatenated fragments).

member.name: M:ModelText.ModelEditControl.IModelEdit.createEditorTransaction
member.summary: Gets a instance, which helps to combine several DOM edits into a single transaction, which can be undone and redone as if they were a single, atomic operation.
member.returns: A instance.

member.name: P:ModelText.ModelEditControl.IModelEdit.formDataset
member.summary: Gets a string which contains the values of all the successful controls within an HTML form.
member.remarks:
Only the contents of "successful" controls are returned, as defined in the W3C specification.
The contents of successful controls are concatenated and returned as a single string. The format of the string matches the application/x-www-form-urlencoded content type.
You will want to call this property from the method in your application which is invoked when the user presses the form's Submit button (see for further details).

member.name: P:ModelText.ModelEditControl.IModelEdit.toolContainer
member.summary: Gets the instance of the interface, which lets you interact with the buttons on the toolbar.

member.name: P:ModelText.ModelEditControl.IModelEdit.domDocument
member.summary: Gets the instance of the interface, which is implemented by the document object that is the root node of the DOM, via which you can subsequently access all the other nodes in the DOM.

member.name: P:ModelText.ModelEditControl.IModelEdit.windowSelection
member.summary: Gets the instance of the interface, via which you can read and write the instances which represent the user's selections (for example, the location of the insertion caret within the DOM).

member.name: P:ModelText.ModelEditControl.IModelEdit.css
member.summary: Sets the CSS which should be used to render the document.
member.remarks: To be effective, this property must be set before the document is loaded and rendered, i.e. before you invoke the , , or methods. If you set this property to null, then the control will use its own built-in style sheet. If you set this property to an empty string, then the control will use no style sheet, in other words it will use a 'reset' style sheet which is based on Appendix D of the CSS specification. After you set this property, its value remains set for the lifetime of the control instance: the same CSS definition will be used for all the HTML that you load and reload into the control. As well as or instead of using this property, you can also use: The style= attribute on specific HTML tags (for example, Foo Bar). The span {display: inline-block}).

member.name: M:ModelText.ModelEditControl.IModelEditControl.emulateModalDialog(System.Windows.Forms.Control,System.Boolean,ModelText.ModelEditControl.OnEscape)
member.summary: Use this method to emulate a modal dialog or popup window.
member.remarks: The control which you pass in as a parameter is displayed on top and in the middle of the edit control, and the edit control itself is greyed. This method is useful when the application is being run with limited UI permissions, such that popping a real dialog in a separate form would result in an ugly/annoying security message displayed to the end user.
member.param:
The user control which implements functionality like a modal dialog.
When the dialog is dismissed, for example when the user presses the dialog's OK or Canel button, then call this method again but specify a null parameter.
Whether the Control that's being passed in is able to accept the input (for keyboard input). If true then the input focus is moved to the new control.

A delegate which is invoked when the user presses the Esc (Escape) key. The caller, which owns the Control dialog, can cancel the dialog (by invoking emulateModalDialog with a null parameter), and then dispose the control.

member.name: M:ModelText.ModelEditControl.IModelEditControl.interceptKeyDown(System.Windows.Forms.KeyEventHandler)
member.summary: This method lets you install a KeyEventHandler handler which intercepts KeyDown events. Your handler can set KeyEventArgs.SuppressKeyPress if it handles the event and wants to prevent the event's being propagated. An application which uses an IModelEdit instance should use this method instead of using, for example, the ToolStripMenuItem.ShortcutKeys property: because the IModelEdit instance is able to accept all keys including left and right arrow as input keys, therefore these keys are not reliably handled by the ToolStripMenuItem.ShortcutKeys property.

member.name: T:ModelText.ModelDom.Events.IDomEventTarget
member.summary: This interface is implemented by all instances, and lets the application install an event handler which will be invoked when various events happen to the node.
member.remarks: For further details, see the W3C EventTarget documentation.

member.name: M:ModelText.ModelDom.Events.IDomEventTarget.addEventListener(ModelText.ModelDom.Events.DomEventType,ModelText.ModelDom.Events.DomEventListener,System.Boolean)
member.summary: This method allows the registration of event listeners on the event target.
member.param: The event type for which the user is registering.
A delegate which represents the application-defined method to be called when the event occurs.

If true, useCapture indicates that the user wishes to initiate capture. After initiating capture, all events of the specified type will be dispatched to the registered EventListener before being dispatched to any EventTargets beneath them in the tree. Events which are bubbling upward through the tree will not trigger an EventListener designated to use capture.
member.remarks: If an EventListener is added to an EventTarget while it is processing an event, it will not be triggered by the current actions but may be triggered during a later stage of event flow, such as the bubbling phase. If multiple identical EventListeners are registered on the same EventTarget with the same parameters the duplicate instances are discarded. They do not cause the EventListener to be called twice and since they are discarded they do not need to be removed with the removeEventListener method.

member.name: M:ModelText.ModelDom.Events.IDomEventTarget.removeEventListener(ModelText.ModelDom.Events.DomEventType,ModelText.ModelDom.Events.DomEventListener,System.Boolean)
member.summary: This method allows the removal of event listeners from the event target.
member.param: Specifies the event type of the EventListener being removed.
The EventListener parameter indicates the EventListener to be removed.

Specifies whether the EventListener being removed was registered as a capturing listener or not. If a listener was registered twice, one with capture and one without, each must be removed separately. Removal of a capturing listener does not affect a non-capturing version of the same listener, and vice versa.
member.remarks: If an EventListener is removed from an EventTarget while it is processing an event, it will not be triggered by the current actions. EventListeners can never be invoked after being removed. Calling removeEventListener with arguments which do not identify any currently registered EventListener on the EventTarget has no effect.

member.name: M:ModelText.ModelDom.Nodes.IDomNode.isSameNode(ModelText.ModelDom.Nodes.IDomNode)
member.summary: Returns whether this node is the same node as the given one.
member.param: The node to test against.
member.returns: Returns true if the nodes are the same, false otherwise.
member.remarks: This method provides a way to determine whether two Node references returned by the implementation reference the same object. When two Node references are references to the same object, even if through a proxy, the references may be used completely interchangeably, such that all attributes have the same values and calling the same DOM method on either reference always has exactly the same effect.

member.name: M:ModelText.ModelDom.Nodes.IDomNode.cloneNode(System.Boolean)
member.summary: Returns a duplicate of this node, i.e., serves as a generic copy constructor for nodes.
member.param: If true, recursively clone the subtree under the specified node; if false, clone only the node itself (and its attributes, if it is a ).
member.returns: The duplicate node.
member.remarks:
The duplicate node has no parent (parentNode is null) and no user data.
Cloning an Element copies all attributes and their values, but this method does not copy any children it contains unless it is a deep clone. This includes text contained in an the Element since the text is contained in a child Text node. Cloning any other type of node simply returns a copy of this node.

member.name: M:ModelText.ModelDom.Nodes.IDomNode.insertBefore(ModelText.ModelDom.Nodes.IDomNode,ModelText.ModelDom.Nodes.IDomNode)
member.summary: Inserts the node newChild before the existing child node refChild.
member.param: The node to insert.
The reference node, i.e., the node before which the new node must be inserted.
member.returns: The node being inserted.
member.remarks: If refChild is null, insert newChild at the end of the list of children. If newChild is a DocumentFragment object, all of its children are inserted, in the same order, before refChild. If the newChild is already in the tree, it is first removed.

member.name: M:ModelText.ModelDom.Nodes.IDomNode.removeChild(ModelText.ModelDom.Nodes.IDomNode)
member.summary: Removes the child node indicated by oldChild from the list of children, and returns it.
member.param: The node being removed.
member.returns: The node removed.

member.name: M:ModelText.ModelDom.Nodes.IDomElement.getAttribute(System.String)
member.summary: Retrieves an attribute value by name
member.param: The name of the attribute to retrieve.
member.returns: The Attr value as a string. The W3C documentation says that this method returns "the empty string if that attribute does not have a specified or default value". However, the current implementation of this method return null. In the future, the implementation may change to match the W3C's specification. If you want to test for a non-existent attribute value, you should therefore use the method on the string value returned by this method.

member.name: M:ModelText.ModelDom.Nodes.IDomElement.setAttribute(System.String,System.String)
member.summary: Adds a new attribute.
member.param: The name of the attribute to create or alter.
Value to set in string form.
member.remarks:
If an attribute with that name is already present in the element, its value is changed to be that of the value parameter. This value is a simple string; it is not parsed as it is being set.
The following sentences from the W3C documentation are not true: "So any markup (such as syntax to be recognized as an entity reference) is treated as literal text, and needs to be appropriately escaped by the implementation when it is written out. In order to assign an attribute value that contains entity references, the user must create an Attr node plus any Text and EntityReference nodes, build the appropriate subtree, and use setAttributeNode to assign it as the value of an attribute."
This sentence isn't true because this API doesn't support entity references, and also doesn't support attributes being accessed as a type of node."To set an attribute with a qualified name and namespace URI, use the setAttributeNS method."
This sentence isn't true because this API doesn't implement a setAttributeNS method, and doesn't support having attributes with a qualified name and namespace URI.

member.name: P:ModelText.ModelDom.Nodes.IDomElement.tagName
member.summary: The name of the element. Note that this is case-preserving in XML.

member.name: P:ModelText.ModelDom.Html.IHtmlElement.id
member.summary: The element's identifier.
member.remarks: See the id attribute definition in HTML 4.01.

member.name: P:ModelText.ModelDom.Html.IHtmlElement.className
member.summary: The class attribute of the element.
member.remarks: This attribute has been renamed due to conflicts with the "class" keyword exposed by many languages. See the class attribute definition in HTML 4.01.

member.name: P:ModelText.ModelDom.Html.IHtmlInputElement.type
member.summary: The type of control created (all lower case).
member.remarks: See the type attribute definition in HTML 4.01.

member.name: P:ModelText.ModelDom.Html.IHtmlInputElement.value
member.summary:
When the type attribute of the element has the value "text", "file" or "password", this represents the current contents of the corresponding form control, in an interactive user agent. Changing this attribute changes the contents of the form control, but does not change the value of the HTML value attribute of the element.
When the type attribute of the element has the value "button", "hidden", "submit", "reset", "image", "checkbox" or "radio", this represents the HTML value attribute of the element.
member.remarks: See the value attribute definition in HTML 4.01.

member.name: P:ModelText.ModelDom.Html.IHtmlInputElement.isChecked
member.summary: When the type attribute of the element has the value "radio" or "checkbox", this represents the current state of the form control, in an interactive user agent. Changes to this attribute change the state of the form control, but do not change the value of the HTML checked attribute of the INPUT element.
member.remarks: This property is named 'checked' in the W3C specification, however 'checked' is a C# keyword so the property is renamed here to 'isChecked'.

member.name: P:ModelText.ModelDom.Html.IHtmlInputElement.name
member.summary: Form control or object name when submitted with a form.
member.remarks: See the name attribute definition in HTML 4.01.

member.name: T:ModelText.ModelDom.Nodes.NamespaceDoc
member.summary:
This namespace includes interfaces to read and write the DOM, after the DOM is loaded into the control.
Most of the interfaces in this namespace are based on a subset of the API defined in the W3C Document Object Model (DOM) Level 3 Core Specification.
See Nodes in the DOM for an overview of the types in this namespace.

member.name: T:ModelText.ModelDom.Events.DomEventType
member.summary: The value of the property.
member.remarks:
The mouse event types are described in the W3C Mouse event types documentation.
The key events are based on de facto (not official) standard: see keydown, keypress, keyup and Key events.

member.name: F:ModelText.ModelDom.Events.DomEventType.Click
member.summary: The click event occurs when the pointing device button is clicked over an element.
member.remarks:
A click is defined as a mousedown and mouseup over the same screen location. The sequence of these events is:
Click

member.name: F:ModelText.ModelDom.Events.DomEventType.Mouseover
member.summary: The mouseover event occurs when the pointing device is moved onto an element. This event is valid for most elements.

member.name: F:ModelText.ModelDom.Events.DomEventType.Mouseout
member.summary: The mouseout event occurs when the pointing device is moved away from an element. This event is valid for most elements.

member.name: F:ModelText.ModelDom.Events.DomEventType.Mousedown
member.summary: The mousedown event occurs when the pointing device button is pressed over an element. This event is valid for most elements.

member.name: F:ModelText.ModelDom.Events.DomEventType.Mouseup
member.summary: The mouseup event occurs when the pointing device button is released over an element. This event is valid for most elements.

member.name: F:ModelText.ModelDom.Events.DomEventType.Mousemove
member.summary: The mousemove event occurs when the pointing device is moved while it is over an element. This event is valid for most elements.

member.name: F:ModelText.ModelDom.Events.DomEventType.Keydown
member.summary: The keydown event occurs when the user depresses a key.

member.name: F:ModelText.ModelDom.Events.DomEventType.Keypress
member.summary: The keypress event occurs when an actual character is being inserted in, for instance, a text input.

member.name: F:ModelText.ModelDom.Events.DomEventType.Keyup

This methods walks every node in the DOM tree, and installs the event handler into every node which matches the predicate. Any nodes which may be added to the tree after this method is called will not have an installed event handler. Therefore, this method is more suitable for use in Forms, which aren't edited by the end user. Instead of using this method, an alternative (perhaps a better alternative) is to install the event handler only into the node (by invoking its
method, and within the event handler applying the predicate to the property of its parameter.

method, specifying false as the useCapture parameter.

member.remarks: Capture happens before bubbling, (as explained in the W3C description of event flow). This method invokes the addListener method with the useCapture parameter set to false: so an event handler installed in this way will be fired after other application-installed event handlers, but before any default event handlers.

member.name: T:ModelText.ModelDom.Range.IWindowSelection
member.summary: This interface represents one or ranges which are selected n the control's user interface, and visible to the end user.
member.remarks:
This interface isn't based on a W3C standard. Instead it's based on de facto interfaces from various browsers. It represents the object that's returned when you invoke the javascript window.getSelection() method as described at Introduction to Range.
The Microsoft Internet Explorer version of this interface is the DHTML selection Object in the Microsoft API.
However this interface is based more on the Mozilla API (instead of the MS IE API). The Mozilla interface can be found at nsISelection.idl and Selection.

When you have finished with the IDomRange instance, invoke its or method.
member.param: An index which specifies which of several ranges should be returned.
member.returns: A instance which represents the selection.
member.remarks: In the current version of the control, the will always be 1 and so the should always be 0.

member.summary: This interface is implemented by the root node of the DOM tree.
member.remarks:
An instance of this interface is returned by the ModelText.ModelEditControl.IModelEdit.domDocument property of the ModelText.ModelEditControl.IModelEdit interface.

member.name: M:ModelText.ModelDom.Nodes.IDomDocument.createElement(System.String)
member.summary: Creates an element of the type specified. Note that the instance returned implements the interface, so attributes can be specified directly on the returned object.
member.param: The name of the element type to instantiate.
member.returns: A new object with the nodeName attribute set to tagName, and localName, prefix, and namespaceURI set to null.
member.remarks:
The following sentences, which are in the original W3C documentation, are not true. "In addition, if there are known attributes with default values, Attr nodes representing them are automatically created and attached to the element."
This is untrue for two reasons:
There are no default attribute values (except 'null').
Attributes aren't represented as 'Attr nodes' in the tree, which can be accessed using the property. Instead, attribute values can be accessed only via the and
methods."For XML, this is case-sensitive, otherwise it depends on the case-sensitivity of the markup language in use. In that case, the name is mapped to the canonical form of that markup by the DOM implementation."
This is untrue because in XHTML the tagName is always case-sensitive: it must be lower-case.

member.name: M:ModelText.ModelDom.Nodes.IDomDocument.createTextNode(System.String)
member.summary: Creates a node given the specified string.
member.param: The data for the node.
member.returns: The new object.

member.name: M:ModelText.ModelDom.Nodes.IDomDocument.getElementById(System.String)
member.summary: Returns the that has an ID attribute with the given value.
member.param: The unique id value for an element.
member.returns: The matching element or null if there is none.
member.remarks:
If no such element exists, this returns null. If more than one element has an ID attribute with that value, what is returned is undefined.
The following sentence, which is in the original W3C documentation, is not true:"The DOM implementation is expected to use the attribute Attr.isId to determine if an attribute is of type ID. Note: Attributes with the name "ID" or "id" are not of type ID unless so defined."
This is untrue because, using XHTML, the 'ID attribute' is the automatically attribute whose name is "id".

member.name: M:ModelText.ModelDom.Nodes.IDomDocument.setTestIsReadonly(System.Predicate{ModelText.ModelDom.Nodes.IDomNode})
member.summary: Lets you install an application-defined method, which lets you specify that some nodes in the DOM should to be read-only or uneditable.
member.param: This is an application-defined method, a predicate. This application-defined predicate should return true, if the specified instance which is passed to it as a parameter should be read-only.
member.remarks:
If a predicate is installed using this method, and if the predicate returns true to specify that an element is read-only, then the end-user cannot place the insertion caret inside that element:
Clicking on the element results in the whole element being selected
Using the cursor keys moves the cursor over or past the whole element, as if the whole element were a single indivisible block of text (which it is)
When the whole element is selected, the end user can delete the whole element: but cannot modify the element.
This does not correspond to a W3C-standard API. The W3C's Open Issues List mentions "adding an isReadonly flag to the Node interface". See also Mutation and mutation name event types which said,
"The mutation and mutation name event modules are designed to allow notification of any changes to the structure of a document, including attribute, text, or name modifications. It may be noted that none of the event types associated with the modules are designated as cancelable. This stems from the fact that it is very difficult to make use of existing DOM interfaces which cause document modifications if any change to the document might or might not take place due to cancelation of the resulting event. Although this is still a desired capability, it was decided that it would be better left until the addition of transactions into the DOM."
These two quotes imply that it's useful to be able to to prevent a document modification: and that's what this method lets you do.

member.name: M:ModelText.ModelDom.Nodes.IDomDocument.setTestAllowInline(ModelText.ModelDom.Events.TestAllowInline)
member.summary: Like setTestIsReadonly this too does not correspond to a W3C-standard API. This method lets the application install a delegate which, if it returns true, specifies that a node is not allowed to contain inline tags (and instead can only contain IDomText nodes). Any restriction on inline children that's specified by this method is in addition to any restriction that's specified by the XHTML schema. The ModelTextApplication uses this to specify that headings can contain only text.

member.name: M:ModelText.ModelDom.Nodes.IDomDocument.addDefaultEventListener(ModelText.ModelDom.Events.DomEventType,ModelText.ModelDom.Events.DomEventListener)
member.summary: Lets you install an event handler, which will help to implement the control's default event handling.
member.remarks:
This method lets the application install a default event handler, whose activation can be cancelled by the method.
This method is not part of the standard W3C DOM API. This method exists to help implement the 'default' event handling which a browser should implement: for example, a W3C topic titled Event cancelation says,
"An example of this is a hyperlink in a web browser. When the user clicks on the hyperlink the default action is generally to active that hyperlink."
There are two standard behaviours which are implemented by a typical web browser, and which cannot be implemented by the control without some application-defined event handler:
Submitting the contents of a web Form, when the user clicks on the Submit button
Navigating to the target of a hyperlink, when the user clicks on an anchor
To install event handlers for these methods, use the and methods of the class (which are implemented by invoking this method).
member.param: The type of event which the specified listener is willing to handle.
An application-defined method, which accepts a instance as a parameter.

member.name: T:ModelText.ModelDom.Range.IDomRange
member.summary: This interface represents a selected range within the document tree.
member.remarks:
This interface implements a subset of the W3C Range interface.
You can use the method to get an instance of this class.

member.name: M:ModelText.ModelDom.Range.IDomRange.detach
member.summary: Called to indicate that the Range is no longer in use and that the implementation may relinquish any resources associated with this Range.
member.remarks:
After to call this method, any subsequent calls to any methods or attribute getters on this Range will result in a being thrown with an error code of .
You should invoke this method as soon as possible. Range instances should not be long-lived, because they may end up pointing to nodes which don't exist in the document (e.g. after the user does some 'Undo' operations). Instead, you should probably instantiate a Range instance, use it, and then detach it, all within the scope of a single synchronous event handler.
The IDomRange interface also implements the IDisposable interface, and the Dispose method invokes the detach method.

member.remarks: If the container is a node, this will be split at the start of the Range (as if the Text node's method was performed at the insertion point) and the insertion will occur between the two resulting Text nodes. Adjacent Text nodes will not be automatically merged. If the node to be inserted is a node, the children will be inserted rather than the DocumentFragment node itself.

member.name: M:ModelText.ModelDom.Html.IHtmlFormElement.serialize
member.summary: Serializes the contents of the form's sucessful controls into a string of data.
member.returns: A text string in standard URL-encoded notation.
member.remarks:
Serialize is typically used to prepare user input data to be posted to a server. The serialized data is in a standard format that is compatible with almost all server side programming languages and frameworks. In order to work properly serialize requires that form fields have a name attribute. Having only an id will not work.
This isn't a method in the W3C standard; instead it's analogous to the jQuery serialize method.
This method returns the same string as the formDataset property of the IModelEdit interface in the ModelText.ModelEditControl namespace.

member.name: M:ModelText.ModelDom.Events.IDomEvent.stopPropagation
member.summary: The stopPropagation method is used prevent further propagation of an event during event flow.
member.remarks: If this method is called by any EventListener the event will cease propagating through the tree. The event will complete dispatch to all listeners on the current EventTarget before event flow stops. This method may be used during any stage of event flow.

member.name: M:ModelText.ModelDom.Events.IDomEvent.preventDefault
member.summary: If an event is cancelable, the preventDefault method is used to signify that the event is to be canceled, meaning any default action normally taken by the implementation as a result of the event will not occur.
member.remarks: If, during any stage of event flow, the preventDefault method is called the event is canceled. Any default action associated with the event will not occur. Calling this method for a non-cancelable event has no effect. Once preventDefault has been called it will remain in effect throughout the remainder of the event's propagation. This method may be used during any stage of event flow.

member.summary: The purpose of this interface is to group several edit actions into a logically-single operation. Without this, each action would undo one at a time. With this, a single undo will affect all actions in the transaction

member.name: T:ModelText.ModelDom.Nodes.DomException
member.summary: An instance of this class may be thrown as an exception, if the application mis-uses the API in some way.
member.remarks: For further details, see the W3C DOMException documentation.

member.name: P:ModelText.ModelDom.Nodes.DomException.code
member.summary: This property returns a value which indicates the cause of this exception instance.

member.name: T:ModelText.ModelDom.Nodes.DomException.Code
member.summary: This enum represents the various code which indicate the type of error that is indicated when a instance is thrown.
member.remarks: For further details, see the W3C ExceptionCode documentation.

member.name: F:ModelText.ModelDom.Nodes.DomException.Code.INDEX_SIZE_ERR
member.summary: If index or size is negative, or greater than the allowed value.

member.name: F:ModelText.ModelDom.Nodes.DomException.Code.DOMSTRING_SIZE_ERR
member.summary: If the specified range of text does not fit into a DOMString.

member.name: F:ModelText.ModelDom.Nodes.DomException.Code.HIERARCHY_REQUEST_ERR
member.summary: If any Node is inserted somewhere it doesn't belong.

member.name: F:ModelText.ModelDom.Nodes.DomException.Code.WRONG_DOCUMENT_ERR
member.summary: If a Node is used in a different document than the one that created it (that doesn't support it).

member.name: F:ModelText.ModelDom.Nodes.DomException.Code.INVALID_CHARACTER_ERR
member.summary: If an invalid or illegal character is specified, such as in an XML name.

member.name: F:ModelText.ModelDom.Nodes.DomException.Code.NO_DATA_ALLOWED_ERR
member.summary: If data is specified for a Node which does not support data.

member.name: F:ModelText.ModelDom.Nodes.DomException.Code.NO_MODIFICATION_ALLOWED_ERR
member.summary: If an attempt is made to modify an object where modifications are not allowed.
member.remarks: Many DOM methods raise this exception "when the node is readonly".

member.name: F:ModelText.ModelDom.Nodes.DomException.Code.NOT_FOUND_ERR
member.summary: If an attempt is made to reference a Node in a context where it does not exist.

member.name: F:ModelText.ModelDom.Nodes.DomException.Code.NOT_SUPPORTED_ERR
member.summary: If the implementation does not support the requested type of object or operation.

member.name: F:ModelText.ModelDom.Nodes.DomException.Code.INUSE_ATTRIBUTE_ERR
member.summary: If an attempt is made to add an attribute that is already in use elsewhere.

member.name: F:ModelText.ModelDom.Nodes.DomException.Code.INVALID_STATE_ERR
member.summary: If an attempt is made to use an object that is not, or is no longer, usable.

member.name: F:ModelText.ModelDom.Nodes.DomException.Code.SYNTAX_ERR
member.summary: If an invalid or illegal string is specified.

member.name: F:ModelText.ModelDom.Nodes.DomException.Code.INVALID_MODIFICATION_ERR
member.summary: If an attempt is made to modify the type of the underlying object.

member.name: F:ModelText.ModelDom.Nodes.DomException.Code.NAMESPACE_ERR
member.summary: If an attempt is made to create or change an object in a way which is incorrect with regard to namespaces.

member.name: F:ModelText.ModelDom.Nodes.DomException.Code.INVALID_ACCESS_ERR
member.summary: If a parameter or an operation is not supported by the underlying object.

member.name: F:ModelText.ModelDom.Nodes.DomException.Code.VALIDATION_ERR
member.summary: If a call to a method such as insertBefore or removeChild would make the Node invalid with respect to "partial validity", this exception would be raised and the operation would not be done. This code is used in [DOM Level 3 Validation]. Refer to this specification for further information.
member.remarks: See http://www.w3.org/TR/DOM-Level-3-Core/glossary.html#dt-partially-valid and http://www.w3.org/TR/2004/REC-DOM-Level-3-Val-20040127/

member.name: F:ModelText.ModelDom.Nodes.DomException.Code.TYPE_MISMATCH_ERR
member.summary: If the type of an object is incompatible with the expected type of the parameter associated to the object.

member.summary: This method is used to get the computed style as it is defined in CCS2.

The pseudo-element or null if none.

member.name: M:ModelText.ModelCssInterfaces.View.ICssViewCss.getSpecifiedStyle(ModelText.ModelCssInterfaces.Dom.IDomElement,ModelText.ModelCssInterfaces.Dom.PseudoElements)
member.summary: This method is of my own invention. It's used in the API between the in-browser DOM and the parsed CSS. It's better than the official method because it allows more than one ICssPseudo instance and a more accurate implementation of partial match based on a function as described at http://www.w3.org/TR/CSS21/selector.html#lang

member.name: M:ModelText.ModelCssInterfaces.View.ICssViewCss.getSpecifiedAnonymousChildStyle(ModelText.ModelCssInterfaces.Dom.IDomElement,ModelText.ModelCssInterfaces.Dom.PseudoElements)
member.summary: This method is similar to getSpecifiedStyle except that it's used to get the style of an anonymous child block the rules for which are described at http://www.w3.org/TR/CSS2/visuren.html#anonymous-block-level

member.name: M:ModelText.ModelCssInterfaces.View.ICssViewCss.resetCache
member.summary: This method is of my own invention. It's used in the API between the in-browser DOM and the parsed CSS. The results returned by getSpecifiedStyle are based on cached values calculated for IDomElement values. Some of these IDomElement instance are local to a specific HTML document, e.g. the instances which contain id attributes. If the same ICssViewCss instance is reused for multiple documents, then the cache can fill with entries which don't exist in the current document. It's recommended that you call this method in between each document.

member.name: T:ModelText.ModelCssInterfaces.View.ICssStyleDeclaration
member.summary: This interface is based on a subset of the DOM CSSStyleDeclaration interface.
member.remarks:
The CSS2Properties documentation says, "If an implementation does implement this interface, the expectation is that language-specific methods can be used to cast from an instance of the CSSStyleDeclaration interface to the CSS2Properties interface".
The "language-specific method" which I use here is to say that inherits from .

member.name: T:ModelText.ModelCssInterfaces.View.ICss2Properties
member.summary: This interface is based on a subset of the DOM CSS2Properties interface.
member.remarks: Instead of returning string values as defined in the standard, I find it more useful to return instances (which because they are parsed values are easier for client software to make use of). You can easily convert a ICssValue instance to a string: simply get its cssText property.

member.name: T:ModelText.ModelCssInterfaces.Parsed.ICssSelectorSimpleQualifierPseudo
member.summary: This interface models an instance of a pseudo-element or pseudo-class as defined at http://www.w3.org/TR/CSS21/selector.html#pseudo-elements http://www.w3.org/TR/CSS21/selector.html#pseudo-class-selectors http://www.w3.org/TR/CSS21/selector.html#pseudo-element-selectors Instances of this interface are returned by the property.
member.remarks:
The contents of this element correspond to the following lines of the CSS Grammar:
pseudo : ':' [ IDENT | FUNCTION S* IDENT? S* ')' ] ;

member.name: P:ModelText.ModelCssInterfaces.Parsed.ICssSelectorSimpleQualifierPseudo.id

member.name: P:ModelText.ModelCssInterfaces.Parsed.ICssSelectorSimpleQualifierPseudo.function

member.summary: This represents a set of zero or more pseudoElement strings, which are defined in the CSS using and which are selected by the application using .

remarks.para:
An instance of this interface is:
Returned by the property
Filtered using the instance which is passed as a parameter to the method.
Passed as an input parameter to the method.
The class which implements this interface overrides the Equals and GetHashCode methods, and is immutable: so, it can be equated by value, and used as the key of a dictionary.

.

member.name: T:ModelText.ModelCssInterfaces.Parsed.ICssStylesheet
member.summary: The top-level element, which represents the whole stylesheet. An instance of this interface is returned by the parseStylesheet method of the ModelText.ModelCssParser.CssParserFactory class.
member.remarks:
The contents of this element correspond to the following lines of the CSS Grammar:
stylesheet : [ CHARSET_SYM STRING ';' ]? [S|CDO|CDC]* [ import [S|CDO|CDC]* ]* [ [ ruleset | media | page ] [S|CDO|CDC]* ]* ;

member.remarks: See also the , , and properties, which return the objects of a particular types.

term : unary_operator? [ NUMBER S* | PERCENTAGE S* | LENGTH S* | EMS S* | EXS S* | ANGLE S* | TIME S* | FREQ S* ] | STRING S* | IDENT S* | URI S* | hexcolor | function ;

member.name: F:ModelText.ModelCssView.Origin.UserAgent
member.summary: Conforming user agents must apply a default style sheet (or behave as if they did). A user agent's default style sheet should present the elements of the document language in ways that satisfy general presentation expectations for the document language (e.g., for visual browsers, the EM element in HTML is presented using an italic font). See A sample style sheet for HTML for a recommended default style sheet for HTML documents.

member.name: F:ModelText.ModelCssView.Origin.User
member.summary: The user may be able to specify style information for a particular document. For example, the user may specify a file that contains a style sheet or the user agent may provide an interface that generates a user style sheet (or behaves as if it did).

member.name: F:ModelText.ModelCssView.Origin.Author
member.summary: The author specifies style sheets for a source document according to the conventions of the document language. For instance, in HTML, style sheets may be included in the document or linked externally.

member.name: P:ModelText.ModelException.LogUnhandledException.extraInformation
member.summary: Gets or sets whether extra information will be inserted in the log file if there's an unhandled exception. Setting this property to true might be necessary in order to help debug an unhandled exception.
member.remarks: If this property is set to true, then the control is slightly (although perhaps unnoticeably) slower at run-time: because the extra information is being prepared continuously whether or not there's an exception (so that it exists pre-prepared if there ever is an exception.

member.name: P:ModelText.ModelException.LogUnhandledException.fullPathOfLogFile
member.summary: Gets or sets the path of the file to which the unhandled exception is logged. If you don't explicitly set the value of this property before you invoke the method, then the value returned by the property is used instead.

member.name: P:ModelText.ModelException.LogUnhandledException.defaultPathOfLogFile
T:ModelText.ModelException.NamespaceDoc
member.summary:
This namespace includes a class which can generate a log file to help debug any unhandled exceptions.
See Technical support for further details.
